analyzed: mohaḥ nidānam doṣāṇām etat eva abhidhīyate
translated: Delusion is said to be the cause of faults,

analyzed: satkāya dṛṣṭeḥ anyatra tad prahāṇe prahāṇataḥ iti
translated: because their abandonment is due to the abandonment of the view of the transitory collection, apart from that.

analyzed: samartha kāraṇa sattve kārya sattvam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The meaning is that when the efficient cause exists, the effect exists.

original: sarvaḍākinīparṣadbhūtaṃ śrīherukasaṃyogaṃ tādṛśa evāhaṃ vakṣye iti samudāyārthaḥ /🔽svayambhūriti kāryakāraṇabhāvādinā svayameva sanniti kecit na ca kāryakāraṇāditi bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: sarva ḍākinī parṣad bhūtam śrīheruka saṃyogam tādṛśaḥ eva aham vakṣye iti samudāya arthaḥ  svayambhūḥ iti kārya kāraṇa bhāva ādinā svayam eva san iti kecid na ca kārya kāraṇāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The collective meaning is that I will speak of the union of the glorious Heruka, who is endowed with all the assemblies of Dakinis, in that way.🔽Some say that the self-arisen one exists by itself through the relation of cause and effect, etc., and not as an effect of something else.

original: paramārthataḥ sanna tāvat kāryaṃ pratyutpannaṃ sadasatorutpādavigamāt /
analyzed: paramārthataḥ sat na tāvat kāryam pratyutpannam sat asatoḥ utpāda vigamāt
translated: An effect, which is present, does not exist ultimately, because of the absence of the production of an existent or non-existent thing.

analyzed: yatas sataḥ na utpattiḥ
translated: Because there is no production of an existent thing.

analyzed: vidyamāna tvāt
translated: Because it already exists.

analyzed: kāraṇa abhimata bhāvavat
translated: Like a thing that is considered to be a cause.

analyzed: punarutpādaḥ ced
translated: If there is a further production,

analyzed: bhāva anivṛttiḥ prasajyet
translated: the non-cessation of an existent thing would follow.

analyzed: atha nivṛttiḥ
translated: Or if there is cessation,

analyzed: pūrva bhāva vināśāt apūrva utpattau na sataḥ utpādaḥ
translated: in the destruction of a previous thing and the arising of a new one, there is no production of an existent thing.

analyzed: tatra pūrvasya vināśa upūrvasya utpādaḥ astu nāma
translated: Let there be the destruction of the previous thing and the arising of a new one.

analyzed: tathā api sataḥ utpattiḥ
translated: Even so, there is the production of an existent thing.

analyzed: apūrvasya sataḥ utpattiḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that there is the production of an existent new thing,

analyzed: na sataḥ pūrva tvasya hānāt
translated: no, because the previous existence is lost.

original: hānau hi pūrvasya sato vidyamānatvādavidyamānavadutpādāyoga ityapi na sata utpādaḥ /
analyzed: hānau hi pūrvasya sataḥ vidyamāna tvāt avidyamāna vat utpāda ayogaḥ iti api na sataḥ utpādaḥ
translated: For if there is destruction, then because what previously existed would be existent, it is not possible for it to arise as if it were non-existent. Thus, there is no arising of what exists.

original: na ca yadi sata utpattirnāsti sadeva tatkatham /
analyzed: na ca yadi sataḥ utpattiḥ na asti sat eva tat katham
translated: And if there is no arising of what exists, how can it be existent?

analyzed: na hi anutpannāḥ śaśaviṣāṇa ādayaḥ santaḥ
translated: For horns of a rabbit, etc., which do not arise, are not existent.

analyzed: sāmarthya lakṣaṇam hi sattvam
translated: For existence is characterized by capability.

original: arthakriyāyāmanupayoge nityāḥ padārthā naraviṣāṇādivanna kasyacidarthakriyārthina upādeyāḥ /
analyzed: arthakriyāyām anupayoge nityāḥ padārthāḥ nara viṣāṇa ādi vat na kasyacid arthakriyā arthinaḥ upādeyāḥ
translated: If they are not useful in effective action, then eternal things, like the horns of a man, are not to be accepted by anyone who desires effective action.

analyzed: utpattau vā sataḥ tebhyaḥ stasyāḥ
translated: Or if there is arising of what exists, then that arising

analyzed: na utpādaḥ niṣiddha tvāt
translated: is not from them. Because it has been refuted.

analyzed: na api asataḥ
translated: Nor is it from what does not exist.

analyzed: niṣedhyamāna tvāt
translated: Because it is being refuted.

analyzed: na ca sat asataḥ  paraspara parhāra avasthiteḥ eka aneka tva abhāvāt
translated: Nor from both what exists and what does not exist.🔽Because they are mutually contradictory and there is no unity or multiplicity.

analyzed: anubhaya pakṣasya ca yugapad sat asat pratiṣedha rupa tvāt
translated: And because the party of neither is of the nature of the denial of both existence and non-existence simultaneously.

original: sadasadviparītvena na ca 🔽sadasadrūpa eva pātena pṛthagasambhavāt /🔽sambhave ca tasyānityābhimatahetukāryatāyāṃ niyamena sattvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: sat asat viparītvena na ca  sat asat rūpe eva pātena pṛthak asambhavāt  sambhave ca tasya anitya abhimata hetu kārya tāyām niyamena sattva prasaṅgāt
translated: And not by the form of both existence and non-existence,🔽because it is not possible separately due to the contradiction of existence and non-existence.🔽And if it were possible, then because it would necessarily exist in the case of the impermanent effect and cause,

analyzed: satkārya vāda niṣedhasya prastuta tvāt
translated: the refutation of the doctrine of the effect pre-existing in the cause would be relevant.

analyzed: sataḥ ca utpāda yogāt arthakriyā upayoga abhāve sāmānyena sarva bhāvānām eka aneka svabhāva viyogena utpāda niṣedhena ca niḥsvabhāva tvasya pratipādayiṣyamāṇa tvāt anutpatti sa  ma
translated: And because of the connection with production, and the absence of connection with the function of an existent, and because of the teaching of the absence of intrinsic nature in general of all existents by the negation of production due to the absence of a single or multiple nature, and by the negation of production, the non-production of the existent and the non-existent is established.

analyzed: ntosantaḥ eva nityāḥ
translated: The eternal ones are indeed non-existent.

original: atra pratisamādhīyate prāgutpādāt sato'sato vā syādutpādaḥ /
analyzed: atra pratisamādhīyate prāk utpādāt sataḥ usataḥ vā syāt utpādaḥ
translated: Here it is replied: Let there be production of the existent or non-existent prior to production.

analyzed: yadi sataḥ tadā na sataḥ
translated: If it is of the existent, then not of the existent.

analyzed: sarva ātmanā tasya siddha sattāka tvāt
translated: Because its existence is already established in every way.

analyzed: na api asataḥ tasya api niṣedhyamāna tvāt
translated: Nor of the non-existent, because that is also being negated.

analyzed: atha śakti rupeṇa kāraṇa ātmani sataḥ vyakti ātma tayā utpādaḥ
translated: Now, if production is of the existent in the form of potentiality in the nature of the cause, and of the manifest nature,

original: sā vyaktirutpādātmikā kiṃ satyasatī vā /🔽kāraṇavyāpārāt pūrvaṃ yadi satī /
analyzed: sā vyaktiḥ utpāda ātmikā kim satī asatī vā  kāraṇa vyāpārāt pūrvam yadi satī
translated: is that manifest existent or non-existent?🔽If it is existent prior to the operation of the cause,

analyzed: śakti vat na janyeta hetunā pūrva uktayā rītyā
translated: it would not be produced by the cause, like potentiality, by the previously stated method.

analyzed: atha asatī sadā satkārya vādaḥ prahīyeta
translated: If it is non-existent, the doctrine of the eternal existence of the effect would be abandoned.

analyzed: a svat kāya vādaḥ ca prasajyeta
translated: And the doctrine of non-causality would follow.

analyzed: śakti vyaktyoḥ eka ātmaka tve sat asat pakṣa bhāvī doṣaḥ syāt
translated: If potentiality and manifestation have the same nature, the fault belonging to the positions of existence and non-existence would occur.

analyzed: bhinna ātmaka tve tu pūrva uktaḥ eva
translated: But if they have different natures, the previously stated [fault] applies.

analyzed: atha kā iyam śaktiḥ
translated: Now, what is this potentiality?

analyzed: kim kāraṇasya ātmā kāryasya vā
translated: What is the cause of the effect?

original: kāraṇatmakatve tadevotpatteḥ prāk sat kāryamiti satkāryavāhadahāniḥ /
analyzed: kāraṇa ātmaka tve tat eva utpatteḥ prāk sat kāryam iti satkārya vāha da hāniḥ
translated: If it is of the nature of the cause, then the effect exists before its production, which contradicts the doctrine of the existence of the effect.

analyzed: kārya ātmaka tve na kārya kāle śaktiḥ
translated: If it is of the nature of the effect, then the potency does not exist at the time of the effect.

original: tadātmakatvānna prāgiti kutaḥ kāraṇātmani śaktyātmanā satkāryam /
analyzed: tad ātmaka tvāt na prāk iti kutas kāraṇa ātmani śakti ātmanā satkāryam
translated: Since it is of the nature of that [effect], it does not exist before. How can the existent effect exist in the form of potency in the cause?

analyzed: atas na śaktiḥ
translated: Therefore, it is not potency.

analyzed: nā api vyaktiḥ saṃbhāvinī
translated: Nor is manifestation possible.

original: śakteḥ kāryakāraṇābhyāmarthāntarabhūtatve tattvā nyatvābhyāmavācyatve na śaktirna kāryaṃ na ca kāraṇaṃ syāt /
analyzed: śakteḥ kārya kāraṇābhyām artha antara bhūta tve tattva a nya tvābhyām avācya tve na śaktiḥ na kāryam na ca kāraṇam syāt
translated: If potency is something different from cause and effect, and is inexpressible as identical or different, then there would be no potency, no effect, and no cause.

original: yacca na kāryaṃ na kāraṇaṃ tanna kasyacida vagrāhakaṃ pratighātakaṃ ceti /
analyzed: yat ca na kāryam na kāraṇam tat na kasyacid a vagrāhakam pratighātakam ca iti
translated: And that which is neither effect nor cause cannot be grasped or obstructed by anything.

original: na mumukṣūṇāmaparasyāpi bhāvajātasya sarvasya kāryakāraṇabhāvaniṣedhena pratighātatayā viṣayatvasiddhau cetaso'viparyāsānmuktisiddheriṣṭatvāt
analyzed: na mumukṣūṇām aparasya api bhāva jātasya sarvasya kārya kāraṇa bhāva niṣedhena pratighāta tayā viṣaya tva siddhau cetasaḥ viparyāsāt mukti siddheḥ iṣṭa tvāt
translated: And because it is accepted that liberation is established by the non-erroneousness of the mind when the existence of all other things is established as the object of obstruction by the negation of the relation of cause and effect between them,

original: na ca śaktiḥ śaktimato'rthāntarabhūtā svarupeṇa ghaṭādivadupalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptā bhedena no u 🔽palabhyate /
analyzed: na ca śaktiḥ śaktimataḥ ṛtha antara bhūtā sva rupeṇa ghaṭa ādi vat upalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptā bhedena no u 🔽palabhyate
translated: and potency is not perceived separately as an object of perception like a pot, etc., in its own form as something different from the potent thing.

original: nāpyanupalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptā tatkāryeṇa samagrakāraṇena śaktyabhāve tadbhāve ca bhavatā cakṣurādivadvijñānakāryeṇonnīyamānasattākā śakyate
analyzed: na api anupalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptā tad kāryeṇa samagra kāraṇena śakti abhāve tad bhāve ca bhavatā cakṣuḥ ādi vat vijñāna kāryeṇa unnīyamāna sattākā śakyate
translated: Nor can it be said to be not perceived, because it is not susceptible of being perceived, since its effect, the visual consciousness, etc., is not produced even when its cause is present, like the visual organ, etc.

analyzed: sat rūpasya eva kāryasya kartum aśakya tvāt
translated: Because it is impossible to produce an existent effect.

analyzed: tad abhāvena dṛṣṭānta asiddheḥ
translated: And because the example is not established without that.

analyzed: tattva anyatva a vācyā api sāmānya nyāya tvāt anena eva krameṇa pratikṣiptā veditavyā
translated: And the universal, which cannot be said to be either the same as or different from the particulars, should be understood to be refuted by this very sequence, because it is a universal.

analyzed: tathā sarve api unupalabdhi lakṣaṇa prāptāḥ veditavyāḥ
translated: And in the same way, all [entities] should be understood to be susceptible of being perceived.

original: nanūtpāde sati sattvaṃ bhāvasyātmeti kathaṃ sadbhāvaḥ /🔽athotpādamantareṇa sat parikalpyate /
analyzed: nanu utpāde sati sattvam bhāvasya ātmā iti katham sadbhāvaḥ  atha utpādam antareṇa sat parikalpyate
translated: But if existence is the self of an entity when it is produced, how can it be existent?🔽Or if existence is imagined to be without production,

analyzed: tadā utpādāt prāk anutpanna abhāvaḥ san uktaḥ syāt
translated: then an existent entity that is not produced prior to production would be stated.

analyzed: sattva arthaḥ hi bhāvanām utpādaḥ iṣyate
translated: For the meaning of existence is accepted as production.

analyzed: yadi ca utpādam antareṇa sattvam siddhyate
translated: And if existence is established without production,

analyzed: tadā kimutpādena  bhavatu anutpannaḥ bhāvaḥ iti ced
translated: then what is the use of production?🔽If it is said that let there be an entity that is not produced,

analyzed: na tatra pūrva abhihitāt doṣāt punar abhidhāsyamāna tvāt ca
translated: no, because the fault stated earlier will be stated again.

original: athotpādāt pūrvasya sataḥ kaścidasanna bhāgaḥ /🔽tadarthatotpādo na niṣphala ityayamapi pakṣo na ghaṭate /
analyzed: atha utpādāt pūrvasya sataḥ kaścid asat na bhāgaḥ  tad artha tā utpādaḥ na niṣphalaḥ iti ayam api pakṣaḥ na ghaṭate
translated: Or if a part of the existent prior to origination is non-existent,🔽then origination is not purposeless. This position also does not hold.

analyzed: satkārya vāda prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would lead to the doctrine of the effect being existent.

analyzed: sat asatoḥ eka tva asambhave sattvasya asattvasya ca
translated: Because existence and non-existence cannot be one, and existence and non-existence would be separate.

analyzed: tatra doṣasya pratipādita tvāt
translated: Because the fault in that has been explained.

analyzed: vyakti pakṣasya pūrvam eva nirākṛta tvāt
translated: Because the position of the individual has already been refuted earlier.

analyzed: atha upādeyaḥ sattasya asataḥ utpāda eti ced
translated: If it is argued that the existent is to be produced,

analyzed: asya api pakṣasya a yujyamāna tvāt
translated: because this position is also unreasonable,

original: tathā hi prathamotpādādeva siddhasarvātma rupasya sato dvitīyotpādasya vaiyarthyāt /
analyzed: tathā hi prathama utpādāt eva siddha sarva ātma rupasya sataḥ dvitīya utpādasya vaiyarthyāt
translated: it is like this: Because the second origination is purposeless for what is already established with all its aspects from the very first origination,

analyzed: satkārya vādasya prakṛta tvāt  pūrva utpādāt api pūrva sataḥ pūrva utpāda ayogāt
translated: because the doctrine of the effect being existent is the topic,🔽and because it is not possible for what is already existent prior to the first origination to originate again.

original: anutpannapakṣasya prāgeva nirākṛtatvāditi sarvathā sata utpādo na yujyate /
analyzed: anutpanna pakṣasya prāk eva nirākṛta tvāt iti sarvathā sataḥ utpādaḥ na yujyate
translated: Because the position of non-origination has already been refuted earlier. Thus in every way, the origination of the existent is not tenable.

original: yadi sata utpādo nāstyasatastarhiṃ kiṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: yadi sataḥ utpādaḥ na asti asataḥ tarhim kim bhaviṣyati
translated: If there is no origination of the existent, then what will there be of the non-existent?

original: tathā hi kalalādiṣu kāraṇeṣu śataśo vikīryamāṇeṣvapi pāṇipādādyavayavasamudāyātmakaṃ śarīraṃ kārmupalabdhilakṣaṇaprāptaṃ yannopalabhyatev tadasadeva
analyzed: tathā hi kalala ādiṣu kāraṇeṣu śataśas vikīryamāṇeṣu api pāṇi pāda ādi avayava samudāya ātmakam śarīram kārmupa labdhi lakṣaṇa prāptam yat na upalabhyate iva tat asat eva
translated: For example, even when the causes such as the kalala (embryonic stage) are scattered in hundreds, the body consisting of the collection of parts such as hands and feet, which is not perceived as having the nature of being perceptible, does not exist.

analyzed: tathā hi purovarti nīla ādiḥ upākāram cakṣuḥ vijñānam anyat
translated: For example, when there is form, light, eye, and attention, the visual consciousness appearing as blue, etc. in front is not the visual consciousness.

original: śrotraśabdamanaskāreṣu veṇuvīṇādinīlalohitādivācakāvācakamanojñāmanojñādiśabdanirbhāsaṃ na śrotravijñānaṃ sat /🔽campakavakulādimanojñāmanojñamadhyamagandhābhāsaṃ nāsikājñāṇaṃ na nāsāgandhamanaskāreṣu vidyamānam /
analyzed: śrotra śabda manaskāreṣu veṇu vīṇā ādi nīla lohita ādi vācaka avācaka manojña amanojña ādi śabda nirbhāsam na śrotra vijñānam sat  campaka vakula ādi manojña amanojña madhyama gandha ābhāsam nāsikā jñāṇam na nāsā gandha manaskāreṣu vidyamānam
translated: When there is ear, sound, and attention, the auditory consciousness appearing as the sounds of flutes, lutes, etc., as expressive or inexpressive, pleasant or unpleasant, etc., does not exist.🔽The olfactory consciousness appearing as the pleasant or unpleasant medium smell of champak flowers, vakula flowers, etc. does not exist among the nose, smell, and attention.

analyzed: rasanā rasa manaskāreṣu kaṭu tikta kaṣāya ādi rasa ābhāsam rasanā jñānam asat
translated: The gustatory consciousness appearing as the tastes of pungent, bitter, astringent, etc. does not exist among the tongue, taste, and attention.

analyzed: na manaḥ kāya praṣṭavyeṣu mṛdu karkaśa ādi spoarśa pratibhāsi kāya vijñānam asti
translated: The tactile consciousness appearing as soft, rough, etc. does not exist among the body, touch, and attention.

original: tathā ṣaṇṇāmanantarātītaṃ vijñānaṃ yaddhi tanmanaḥ iti vacanād /
analyzed: tathā ṣaṇṇām anantara atītam vijñānam yat hi tat manaḥ iti vacanāt
translated: Similarly, because of the statement That which is the immediately past consciousness among the six is the mind,
The subsequent knowledge of the external object, which has the appearance of the immediately past mental activity, is the conceptual cognition that thinks this is blue and so on.

original: na nirvikalpanīlādirupākāra eva jñāne nīlādirupaviṣayamasti /🔽tathā pṛthak pṛthag janakaśabdagandharasasparśapratibhāsikarṇanāsārasanākāyajñānāntarabhāvīnī śabdādikamavastvetaditi vikalpakāni jñānāni nirviklapaśabdādipratibhāsiśrotādijñāneṣu
analyzed: na nirvikalpa nīla ādiḥ upākāraḥ eva jñāne nīla ādiḥ upa viṣayam asti  tathā pṛthak pṛthak janaka śabda gandha rasa sparśa pratibhāsi karṇa nāsā rasanā kāya jñāna antara bhāvīnī śabda ādikam avastu etat iti vikalpakāni jñānāni nirviklapa śabda ādi pratibhāsi śrota ādi jñāneṣu
translated: In the cognition that has the form of blue and so on without conceptualization, there is no external object with the form of blue and so on.🔽Similarly, the conceptual cognitions that think this sound and so on are unreal arise after the separate ear, nose, tongue, and body cognitions that have the appearance of the individual producers, sound, smell, taste, and touch.

analyzed: na vidyante
translated: They do not exist in the ear and so on cognitions that have the appearance of sound and so on without conceptualization.

analyzed: vikalpa jñānam nīlam pītam etat ityādi rupam jāyate
translated: The conceptual cognition arises in the form blue, yellow, this, and so on.

original: na ca tatrāsti kāraṇe nirvikalpādapi purovartinīlādirupapratibhāsinaḥ pūrvasmāt pūrvasmād vijñānāt tadittaramuttaramekasantānasaṃgṛhītadvitīyādikṣaṇabhāvipurovartinīlādirupakṣaṃaparamparāviṣayam
analyzed: na ca tatra asti kāraṇe nirvikalpāt api purovarti nīla ādiḥ upapratibhāsinaḥ pūrvasmāt pūrvasmāt vijñānāt tad ittaram uttaram eka santāna saṃgṛhīta dvitīya ādi kṣaṇa bhāvi purovarti nīla ādiḥ upa kṣaṃ a paramparā viṣayam
translated: And there is no cause for that in the previous cognition that has the appearance of the external blue and so on without conceptualization. The subsequent cognition that has the form of the external blue and so on occurring in the subsequent moments included in the same continuum does not have as its object the external blue and so on occurring in the previous moments.

analyzed: vikalpakam ca jñānam utpadyate
translated: And the conceptual cognition arises.

analyzed: na ca kāraṇe tat asti
translated: And there is no cause for that.

analyzed: evam anyatra api viṣaye draṣṭavyam yatra asi
translated: The same should be seen in other cases as well, where there is
the possibility of a series characterized by a single continuum of the same type.

analyzed: yatra tu na asti santāna eka pravṛttiḥ
translated: But where there is no single continuous activity,

original: tatrāpi sarvathā vicchinnasyaikasyābhāve'nyasya cāvyavadhānena sannidhānena nirvikalpakamindriyajñānam /
analyzed: tatra api sarvathā vicchinnasya ekasya abhāvenyasya ca avyavadhānena sannidhānena nirvikalpakam indriya jñānam
translated: there also, in the absence of a completely disconnected single [object] and the presence of another without interruption, there is a non-conceptual sensory cognition.

original: śabdādiviṣayasamūhena śabdādisamānākāraṃ pūrvaśabdādigrāhiṇi nirvikalpādindriyajñānāduttaraṃ nirvikalpakaṃ savikalpakaṃ ca tadviṣayaṃ jāyate
analyzed: śabda ādi viṣaya samūhena śabda ādi samāna ākāram pūrva śabda ādi grāhiṇi nirvikalpāt indriya jñānāt uttaram nirvikalpakam sa vikalpakam ca tad viṣayam jāyate
translated: In the group of objects such as sound, a non-conceptual and conceptual cognition of that object arises later, having the same form as sound etc., from the non-conceptual sensory cognition that apprehends the previous sound etc.

original: na ca tadasti kāraṇe yathānumutaṃ ghaṇḍākaṃsanādavajjalataraṅgavacca śabdānāṃ santā nena pravṛttiriti tanmate na pūrvaśabdakṣaṇagrāhiṇaḥ śrotrendriyajñānādavikalpakāduttaraśabdakṣaṇagrāhi
analyzed: na ca tat asti kāraṇe yathā anumutam ghaṇḍā kaṃsa nādavat jala taraṅgavat ca śabdānām santā nena pravṛttiḥ iti tad mate na pūrva śabda kṣaṇa grāhiṇaḥ śrotra indriya jñānāt avikalpakāt uttara śabda kṣaṇa grāhi  /
translated: And that does not exist, as it is inferred that the occurrence of sounds is by means of a continuum, like the sound of a bell or the waves of water. According to that view, there is no non-conceptual cognition of the subsequent moment of sound from the sensory cognition of the ear that apprehends the previous moment of sound.

analyzed: nirvikalpakam śrotra indriya jñānam anyat ca sa vikalpakam śabda viṣayam anyat vā jñānam utpadyate
translated: A non-conceptual sensory cognition of the ear and another conceptual cognition of sound or another cognition arises.

analyzed: vyākhyāna kāle ca
translated: And at the time of explanation,

analyzed: pūrva pūrva vikalpāt uttarottaram vikalpakam cetaḥ pravartate
translated: The subsequent conceptual cognition arises from the preceding conceptual cognition.

original: nanu prathamameva vikalpakaṃ kuto na jātam /
analyzed: nanu prathamam eva vikalpakam kutas na jātam
translated: But why does the first conceptual cognition not arise from the non-conceptual cognition itself?

analyzed: yatas uparam sa vikalpakam jāyate
translated: Because the subsequent conceptual cognition arises from that.

analyzed: na atra niyamaḥ asti
translated: There is no rule here.

analyzed: kadācid indriya jñānāt ekasmāt sarvatas vā
translated: Sometimes from one sense cognition, or from all.

analyzed: yathā gāḍha prasuptasya āpāta patita daṇḍa samparkāt upajāta sparśa viṣayaka kāya indriya jñānasya puruṣasya kāya indriya jñānāt bhavati
translated: For example, for a person who is deeply asleep, from the body sense cognition that arises from the contact with a stick that has fallen on him,

original: kadācid mahāśanisannipāte ca buddhasya śrotrendriyajñānāt /🔽kadācidagarukarpūracandanādiparimalāsāditanāsāpuṭavivṛddhaghrāṇendriyajñānād gandhagocarāt /
analyzed: kadācid mahā aśani sannipāte ca buddhasya śrotra indriya jñānāt  kadācid agaru karpūra candana ādi parimala āsādita nāsā puṭa vivṛddha ghrāṇa indriya jñānāt gandha gocarāt
translated: sometimes from the auditory sense cognition of a Buddha at the time of a great thunderbolt strike,🔽sometimes from the olfactory sense cognition of the expanded nose faculty that arises from the fragrance of camphor, agaru, sandalwood, etc., which is the object of smell,

analyzed: kadācid kaṭu tikta kaṣāya ādi dravyeṇa jihvāyāḥ saṃparkāt utpanna rasana indriya jñānāt rasa viṣayāt avikalpakāt
translated: sometimes from the gustatory sense cognition that arises from the contact of the tongue with pungent, bitter, astringent, etc. substances, which is non-conceptual and has taste as its object,

analyzed: kadācid sparśa jñāna antaram unmīlita locanasya guru jana ādi rupam abhivīkṣya cakṣuḥ indriya jñānāt utpadyate
translated: sometimes from the visual sense cognition of one whose eyes are opened after the cognition of touch, upon seeing a venerable person, etc.

original: kadācidastamitasamastendriyajñānasya pūrvasavikalpamanorājyādijñānānukāri savikalpakaṃ jñānaṃ punarvikalpayato jāyate /
analyzed: kadācid astamita samasta indriya jñānasya pūrva sa vikalpa manaḥ rājya ādi jñāna anukāri sa vikalpakam jñānam punar vikalpayataḥ jāyate
translated: Sometimes, when the knowledge of all the senses has set, an indeterminate knowledge arises again for one who imagines, imitating the previous indeterminate mental knowledge, etc.

analyzed: tat eva yugapad indriya jñānataḥ pañcabhyaḥ ṣaḍbhyaḥ vā
translated: That very [knowledge] arises simultaneously from five or six [senses], as from the eye and the mind.

original: yathā ṣaḍvijñānānantaraṃ nidrāvataḥ pūrvacintitasvapne jalpataḥ kathaṃ śaśaviṣāṇāderivāsata utpattiḥ /
analyzed: yathā ṣaṣ vijñāna anantaram nidrāvataḥ pūrva cintita svapne jalpataḥ katham śaśaviṣāṇa ādeḥ iva asataḥ utpattiḥ
translated: How can the arising of a hare's horn, etc., which do not exist, occur like that, as in a dream thought of before by one who is asleep after the six consciousnesses?

analyzed: sarvatas sarva utpatti prasaṅgāt
translated: Because of the consequence that everything would arise from everything.

analyzed: jagataḥ hi upatti ādikam māyā upamam
translated: For the arising, etc. of the world is like an illusion.

analyzed: nanu katham avasīyate nirvikalam indriya jñāna na sa vikalpam iti
translated: But how is it ascertained that sense knowledge without conceptualization is without conceptualization?

original: atra tāvad bahirarthadarśane sautrāntikānāṃ sthitipakṣe bālavyutpattyarthaṃ yathāsmaraṇaṃ diṅmātraṃ kiñcidākhyāyate /
analyzed: atra tāvat bahis artha darśane sautrāntikānām sthiti pakṣe bāla vyutpatti artham yathāsmaraṇam diś mātram kiñcid ākhyāyate
translated: Here, in the Sautrāntika's established position of seeing external objects, something like a direction is explained according to memory for the instruction of the ignorant.

original: tatra jñānaṃ jñeyaṃ ceti dvau bhāvau vyavasthitau /
analyzed: tatra jñānam jñeyam ca iti dvau bhāvau vyavasthitau
translated: There, the two things, knowledge and the knowable, are established.

analyzed: tṛtīya ādiḥ vidyate na aparaḥ
translated: A third, etc. does not exist.

analyzed: kartṛ karaṇa ādīnām tatra eva antarbhāvāt
translated: Because the agent, instrument, etc. are included in those two.

original: tathā hi te kalpyamānāḥ pramāṇāvasāyādipūrvakaṃ kalpanīyāḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi te kalpyamānāḥ pramāṇa avasāya ādi pūrvakam kalpanīyāḥ
translated: For, indeed, when they are imagined, they must be imagined as preceded by valid knowledge, ascertainment, etc.

original: pramāṇanibandhanatvāt padārthavyavasthāyāḥ /🔽anyathedamevaṃ nedamidānīṃ nedānīmidamiti deśakālasvabhāvāntaraparihāreṇa deśāntarādyavagamābhāvād gāḍhasvāpāvasthānam pūrvameva hitāhitaparihānātmakavyavahāravirahitaṃ
analyzed: pramāṇa nibandhana tvāt padārtha vyavasthāyāḥ  anyathā idam evam na idam idānīm na idānīm idam iti deśa kāla svabhāva antara parihāreṇa deśa antara ādi avagama abhāvāt gāḍha svāpa avasthānam pūrvam eva hita ahita parihāna ātmaka vyavahāra virahitam
translated: Because the determination of the meaning of words is based on valid means of knowledge.

analyzed: jagat syāt
translated: Otherwise, this is so, this is not so, this is not now, this is not now, there would be no cognition of other places etc. by excluding other places etc. in space and time, and the world would be in a deep sleep state, devoid of the practical activity of avoiding what is harmful and obtaining what is beneficial, as before.

analyzed: ye tu na arthakriyā kāriṇaḥ śaśaviṣāṇa ādi vat
translated: But those which do not perform any function, like the horn of a hare etc.,

analyzed: te api na bahis avasthitāḥ
translated: they also are not externally situated.

original: kevalamanādivikalpavāsanodbhūtā viklapānividhāyino na parārthikā jñeya yā
analyzed: kevalam anādi vikalpa vāsanā udbhūtāḥ na yā
translated: They are merely produced by the impressions of beginningless conceptualization, and do not establish the distinction of objects for others.

analyzed: eva iti dvau eva bhāvau
translated: Thus there are only two entities.

analyzed: tatra jñāna jñeyayoḥ eka ātmaka tvam na asti
translated: There is no identity of knowledge and the object of knowledge.

analyzed: tad ātmaka tve tu jñānam eva
translated: But if they were of the nature of each other, it would be only knowledge.

analyzed: jñeyam eva advayam
translated: The object of knowledge would be non-dual.

analyzed: tat api vā na syāt ubhaya apekṣa tvāt dvayoḥ
translated: Or even that would not be possible, because of the mutual dependence of the two.

analyzed: jñeya pakṣe andha mūkam jagat syāt
translated: In the case of the object of knowledge, the world would be blind and mute.

original: jñānasyānanyatve jñānapakṣe tu jñeyasya jñānatve bahirarthadarśanamutsīdeta /
analyzed: jñānasya ananya tve jñāna pakṣe tu jñeyasya jñāna tve bahis artha darśanam utsīdeta
translated: If knowledge were not different, but in the case of knowledge, if the object of knowledge were knowledge, the perception of external objects would perish.

analyzed: na ca etat iṣṭam bāhya artha vādinām
translated: And this is not accepted by the proponents of external objects.

original: tatra tayoḥ parasparaparihāreṇāvasthāne jñānātmani jñeyasyāpravresājjñānamevāparaprakāśyatayā prakāśate na jñeyam /
analyzed: tatra tayoḥ paraspara parihāreṇa avasthāne jñāna ātmani jñeyasya a pravresāt jñānam eva apara prakāśya tayā prakāśate na jñeyam
translated: There, when they exist by excluding each other in the knowing self, due to the non-existence of the knowable, only knowledge shines as not being illuminated by another, not the knowable.

analyzed: tasya a prakāśa ātmaka tvāt
translated: Because it is not of the nature of light.

analyzed: tad ātmaka tve pūrva doṣa prasaṅgāt
translated: If it were of that nature, the previously mentioned fault would follow.

analyzed: jñānasya api a prakāśya tve jñeya bhāvī doṣaḥ
translated: If knowledge is also not to be illuminated, the fault that would follow from being a knowable object.

analyzed: para prakāśya tvena pare pi adhikam tasya prakāśa tvam
translated: By being illuminated by another, the other also has more of the nature of light.

analyzed: para upya para prakāśyaḥ syāt itaraḥ vā
translated: The other would also be illuminated by another, or the opposite.

analyzed: anyathā pareṇa prakāśitam idam iti na syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would not be this is illuminated by the other.

analyzed: na syāt
translated: Illuminated would also not be.

analyzed: svayam prakāśa rupam iti eva syāt
translated: It would only be self-luminous.

analyzed: tad prakāśaka a grahaṇe prakāśita tvāt
translated: Because of being illuminated by the apprehension of its illuminator.

analyzed: anyathā anupapattyā tad prakāśa tva pratītiḥ api durlabhā  prakāśaka agrahaṇe prakāśi tva apratipatteḥ
translated: Otherwise, the cognition of its luminous nature is also difficult to obtain by non-apprehension of its illuminator.🔽Because of the non-apprehension of the nature of being illuminated by the non-apprehension of its illuminator.

analyzed: prakāśita tva grahaṇe hi tad anyathā anupapattyā prakāśaka pratītiḥ
translated: For when being illuminated is apprehended, the cognition of its illuminator is by the non-apprehension of its other nature.

analyzed: tad pratītyā ca prakāśita tva pratītuḥ iti anyonya āśraya doṣaḥ
translated: And by the cognition of that, the cognition of being illuminated - this is the fault of mutual dependence.

original: kiñca / yo hi yatsvabhāvo bhāvaḥ sa svabhāvenānyānuparañjayati /
analyzed: kiñca yaḥ hi yad svabhāvaḥ bhāvaḥ sa svabhāvena anyān uparañjayati
translated: Moreover, whatever entity has a certain nature illuminates another by that nature.

original: yathā rāgadravyeṇa saṃyogād dhavalaṃ dravyaṃ bhavati raktam /
analyzed: yathā rāga dravyeṇa saṃyogāt dhavalam dravyam bhavati raktam
translated: For example, a white substance becomes red due to conjunction with the substance of passion.

analyzed: evam kṛṣṇa dravyeṇa kṛṣṇam haritena haritam ityādi
translated: Similarly, it becomes black due to a black substance, green due to a green substance, and so on.

analyzed: pradīpa tejasā aprakāśam prakāśa sahitam rupam bhavet
translated: A form that is not illuminated by the light of a lamp becomes illuminated when accompanied by light.

original: yutpanaḥ svayamaprakāśātmakaṃ tatkathamātmano'paramaprakāśātmakaṃ ptakāśayet /🔽nahi daṇḍenāprakāśātmanā tamasi ghaṭādayaḥ prakāśyante /
analyzed: svayam aprakāśa ātmakam tat katham ātmanā uparama prakāśa ātmakam  nahi daṇḍena aprakāśa ātmanā tamasi ghaṭa ādayaḥ prakāśyante
translated: If it arises by itself as having an unilluminated nature, how could it illuminate another that has an unilluminated nature?🔽For pots and other objects are not illuminated in darkness by a stick that has an unilluminated nature.

analyzed: pradīpa ādīnām anupādāna prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it would follow that lamps and other sources of light would not be used.

analyzed: parasmāt prakāśa bhāvam āsādya aparam prakāśayet iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it illuminates another by attaining the state of light from another,

analyzed: na tatas prakāśa bhāva yogāt
translated: no, because it does not possess the state of light from that.

original: tathāhi yaḥ so'paraḥ sa tāvat svayaṃ prakāśātmā na bhavati paraṃ kathaṃ prakāśayet /
analyzed: tathā hi yaḥ sa uparaḥ sa tāvat svayam prakāśa ātmā na bhavati param katham prakāśayet
translated: For thus, that other which is not itself of the nature of light, how could it illuminate another?

original: tasyāparataḥ prakāśabhāve tasyā'pyaparata ityanavasthānānna kiñcit prakāśyaṃ prakāśakamityandhamūkaṃ jagat syāt /
analyzed: tasya aparatas prakāśa bhāve tasya api aparatas iti anavasthānāt na kiñcid prakāśyam prakāśakam iti andha mūkam jagat syāt
translated: If it has the state of light from another, then that also from another, leading to an infinite regress. Nothing would be illuminated or illuminating. The world would be blind and mute.

analyzed: tatas ca ayam evam na idam iti ādi deśa kāla svabhāva vidhi niṣedha ātma vyavahāra abhāvāt sarvam eva astamitam syāt
translated: And then, because of the absence of all such conventional expressions as 'this is not so', 'here', 'there', 'then', 'now', 'then', 'nature', 'injunction', 'prohibition', 'self', everything would be lost.

analyzed: na ca evam
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: etena itara pakṣaḥ nirākṛtaḥ
translated: By this, the other views are refuted.

analyzed: bhavatu tarhi svayam prakāśa ātmakam jñānam
translated: Well then, let knowledge be of the nature of self-luminous.

original: tathāpi kathaṃ tena jñeyaṃ prakāśitaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tathā api katham tena jñeyam prakāśitam syāt
translated: Even so, how could the knowable be illuminated by it?

original: na hi jñānasvarupaṃ jñeyamāvahati jñeyasvarupaṃ vā jñānam /
analyzed: na hi jñāna svarupam jñeyam āvahati jñeya svarupam vā jñānam
translated: For the form of knowledge does not bring about the knowable, nor does the form of the knowable bring about knowledge.

analyzed: tayoḥ atyanta bhedāt iti pūrvam pratipāditam
translated: Because of the absolute difference between the two, this has been explained earlier.

original: athātyantabhede'pi yathā rāgadravyeṇa śukladravyasya saṃyogād raktatā /
analyzed: atha atyanta bhede pi yathā rāga dravyeṇa śukla dravyasya saṃyogāt rakta tā
translated: If it is argued that even with absolute difference, just as by the conjunction of a red substance with a white substance, there is redness,

original: tamasi sthitānāṃ paṭādīnāṃ yathā vā dīpādiprabhāsvaradravyeṇa sannidhānāt prabhāsvaratā /
analyzed: tamasi sthitānām paṭa ādīnām yathā vā dīpa ādi prabhāsvara dravyeṇa sannidhānāt prabhāsvara tā
translated: or just as by the proximity of a luminous substance like a lamp to cloths etc. that are in darkness, they become luminous,

original: tathā jñānavataḥ sannidhānād jñeyasya prakaśyateti cet /
analyzed: tathā jñānavataḥ sannidhānāt jñeyasya prakaśya tā iti ced
translated: in the same way, the knowable is illuminated by the proximity of one who has knowledge,

analyzed: na jñāna jñeyayoḥ atyanta bhede dṛṣṭānta asiddhiḥ
translated: no. In the absolute difference between knowledge and the knowable, the example is not established.

original: tathā hi dṛṣṭānto nāma jñeyātmako na jñānātmakaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi dṛṣṭāntaḥ nāma jñeya ātmakaḥ na jñāna ātmakaḥ
translated: For an example is of the nature of the knowable, not of knowledge.

original: tayoratyantabhede jñānānmani prakāśātmake pratibhāsamāne tadanātmasvabhāvo dṛṣṭāntaḥ kathaṃ pratibhāseta /
analyzed: tayoḥ atyanta bhede jñānāt mani prakāśa ātmake pratibhāsamāne tad anātma svabhāvaḥ dṛṣṭāntaḥ katham pratibhāseta
translated: If there is absolute difference between the two, how could the example, which is not of the nature of that [knowledge], appear when knowledge, which is of the nature of light, appears?

analyzed: yena dṛṣṭāntaḥ syāt
translated: By what [means] would there be an example?

analyzed: siddhaḥ hi pramāṇena arthaḥ syāt dṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: For an established object by a means of knowledge would be an example.

analyzed: sa ca pramāṇāt bhinna tayā sthitaḥ
translated: And that [example] is established as different from the means of knowledge.

analyzed: tasmin prakāśamāne tad anātmā katham prakāśeta
translated: How could that [object], which is not of the nature of that [means of knowledge], appear when it [the means of knowledge] appears?

original: tato dṛṣṭāntāsiddhyā na kiñcidiṣṭaṃ siddhamiti sarvasattvabadhirādijagat syāt /
analyzed: tatas dṛṣṭānta asiddhyā na kiñcid iṣṭam siddham iti sarva sattva badhira ādi jagat syāt
translated: Therefore, since the example is not established, nothing desired is established. Thus the world of all sentient beings, including the deaf, would exist.

analyzed: tathā hi jñānam utpannam anutpannam vā
translated: For thus, is knowledge arisen or not arisen?

analyzed: utpatti pakṣe rupa ādi kāraṇa sadbhāvaḥ syāt
translated: In the case of arising, there would be the existence of form and other causes.

original: tadabhāve ca sākāraṃ nirākāramanyākāraṃ vā syāt /
analyzed: tad abhāve ca sa ākāram nirākāram anya ākāram vā syāt
translated: And in the absence of that, it would be with form, without form, or with another form.

original: tatrādye pakṣe tādātmyatadutpattibhyāṃ jñeyena jñānasya sambandho nāsti bhedātprakāśātmanā jñeyasya iti kathaṃ kasyacit pratītiḥ syāt /
analyzed: tatra ādye pakṣe tādātmya tad utpattibhyām jñeyena jñānasya sambandhaḥ na asti bhedāt prakāśa ātmanā jñeyasya iti katham kasyacid pratītiḥ syāt
translated: There, in the first case, by identity and origination from that [object], there is no relation between knowledge and the object of knowledge due to difference, and due to the object of knowledge being of the nature of light. Thus how could there be the cognition of anything by anyone?

original: tathā jñeyādanutpannasyta jñānasya nāsti tadākārateti na tadākārajñānavadenamapyarthavedanamaupacārikaṃ siddhyatīti sarvathā nārthapratītiḥ
analyzed: tathā jñeyāt jñānasya nā asti tad ākāra tā iti na tad ākāra jñāna vat enam api artha vedanam aupacārikam siddhi ati iti sarvathā nā artha pratītiḥ
translated: Similarly, for the knowledge that is not produced from the object, there is no having that form. Therefore, like the knowledge that has that form, the experience of that object is also established figuratively. Thus, in every way, there is no cognition of the object.

analyzed: syāt
translated: It would not exist.

analyzed: nitya anitya sattva asattva pakṣāḥ tādātmya tad utpatti abhāve bhedāt tad ākāra tām vihāya pūrvavat na artha pratipatti aṅgam iti na cintanīyāḥ
translated: The positions of permanence, impermanence, existence, and non-existence, in the absence of identity and origination, are different. Apart from having that form, as before, they are not a factor in the cognition of the object. Therefore, they should not be considered.

analyzed: tādāmya tad utpatti abhāve sambandha antara kalpanā nā upapadyate
translated: In the absence of identity and origination, the postulation of another relation is not tenable.

analyzed: tasya upakāra prabhāvita tvāt
translated: Because it is manifested by benefit.

analyzed: anupakāre pūrva doṣa prasaṅgāt
translated: If there is no benefit, the previous fault is entailed.

analyzed: upakāre vā tad utpatti pakṣa prasaṅgāt
translated: If there is benefit, it is entailed that it originates from that.

analyzed: paścāt nirupayiṣyamāṇa tvāt
translated: Because it will be examined later.

analyzed: sarvathā anutpanna pakṣaḥ na anya pratipattau aṅgam
translated: In every way, the position of non-origination is not a factor in the cognition of another.

analyzed: tad abhāva pakṣaḥ tad utpanna pakṣaḥ eva
translated: The position of its absence is just the position of its origination.

original: kevalaṃ tatra nārtho bāhyaṃ kāraṇam /🔽jñānamevārthābhāsaṃ vināpyarthenotpadyate /
analyzed: kevalam tatra na arthaḥ bāhyam kāraṇam  jñānam eva artha ābhāsam vinā api arthena utpadyate
translated: Only there, the external object is not a cause.🔽Knowledge itself arises as the appearance of the object, even without an object.

analyzed: anādi jñāna santāna prabhāvitāt samanantara pratyayāt
translated: From the immediately preceding condition, which is manifested by the beginningless continuum of knowledge.

analyzed: svapna vijñāna vat iti vijñāna vādinaḥ
translated: The Vijñānavādins (Proponents of Consciousness) say, Like a dream consciousness.

original: tathā hi dvāraṃ pidhāya gṛhodare śayitasya nimīlitalocanasya gṛhātiriktapramāṇamātaṅgaturaṅgamādyākāraṃ vijñānaṃ vināpi mātaṅgādibhirarthairutpadyate
analyzed: tathā hi dvāram pidhāya gṛha udare śayitasya nimīlita locanasya gṛha atirikta pramāṇa mātaṅga turaṅgama ādi ākāram vijñānam vinā api mātaṅga ādibhiḥ arthaiḥ utpadyate
translated: For example, when one is lying in the interior of a house with the door closed, with eyes closed, a consciousness arises in the form of elephants, horses, etc. outside the house, even without an elephant, etc. as objects.

original: na ca te svapnapratibhāsino'rthāḥ karituraṅgādayo yujyante /
analyzed: na ca te svapna pratibhāsinā ūrthāḥ kari turaṅga ādayaḥ yujyante
translated: And those objects appearing in a dream, such as elephants, horses, etc., are not reasonable.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ vyāpāra abhāve teṣām pratibhāsanāt
translated: Because they appear in the absence of the functioning of the eyes.

analyzed: nahi nimīlita cakṣuṣā undhasya iva rupa pratibhāsaḥ usti
translated: For one with eyes closed, like one who is blind, there is no appearance of form.

analyzed: cakṣuḥ vyāpārasya api tatra upalambhaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the functioning of the eyes is also perceived there,

analyzed: satyam asti tad upalambhaḥ
translated: it is true that its perception exists.

analyzed: nahi tatra upalambha abhāvaḥ sādhyate pi tu cakṣuḥ indriya abhāvaḥ
translated: For there, the absence of perception is not being proven, but rather the absence of the eye faculty.

original: kathamandhasya suptasya tadabhāve svapne nīlādirupaṃ pratibhāsate /
analyzed: katham andhasya suptasya tad abhāve svapne nīla ādi rupam pratibhāsate
translated: How, in the absence of that, does the form of blue, etc. appear in a dream to one who is blind and asleep?

analyzed: rahite vā vidyante
translated: They exist elsewhere, apart from the dream.

analyzed: teṣām vahni dagdha deha tvāt
translated: Because their bodies are burned by fire.

analyzed: katham vā su alpa āgāra udare mahā pramāṇa medinī nabhaḥ maṇḍala sthitāḥ taru giri sāgara ravi bimba ādayaḥ pratīyante
translated: Or how are the vast earth, sky, trees, mountains, oceans, sun, etc. perceived to exist in the interior of a small house?

original: na hi te tatra praviṣṭāḥ sthitā vā /
analyzed: na hi te tatra praviṣṭāḥ sthitāḥ vā
translated: For they have neither entered nor remained there.

analyzed: supta avasthāyām pratibhā sāvāt
translated: Because there is no appearance in the state of sleep.

original: avikalopalambhakaraṇā hi sādhāraṇamarthajātamupalambhanta eva pumāṃsaḥ sarve /
analyzed: avikala upalambha karaṇāḥ hi sādhāraṇam artha jātam upalambhante eva pumāṃsaḥ sarve
translated: For all men, when the organs of perception are unimpaired, perceive the same objects.

analyzed: yadi ca svapna īrthāḥ santi
translated: And if objects exist in a dream,

original: kathamupādhyāyādayo vyākhyāyāṃ vikurvāṇā tatropalabdhāḥ prabuddhāvasthāyāṃ pṛṣṭāḥ pariharanti /
analyzed: katham upādhyāya ādayaḥ vyākhyāyām vikurvāṇā tatra upalabdhāḥ prabuddha avasthāyām pṛṣṭāḥ pariharanti
translated: how is it that when the teacher and others are engaged in teaching, and are perceived there, they deny it when questioned in the waking state?

analyzed: tat sarvam taiḥ tasya avismṛti tvāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this is because they do not remember it,

analyzed: na sarvadā vismaraṇa abhāvāt
translated: no, because there is no forgetting at all times.

analyzed: yadi nāma vyarthaḥ asti svāpa avasthāyām
translated: If it is said that the state of sleep is indeed useless,

analyzed: kim iyatā dṛṣta anta mātreṇa jāgrat daśāyām artha śūnyam vijñānam siddhi ati
translated: how is it that by this mere example, the consciousness is established as empty of objects in the waking state?

original: nahi taimirikajñānaṃ mithyeti vitimiraṃ jñānaṃ mithyā syāt /
analyzed: nahi taimirika jñānam mithyā iti vitimiram jñānam mithyā syāt
translated: For the knowledge of one with eye disease is not false, the knowledge without eye disease would not be false.

analyzed: tathā hi tat vijñānam abhrāntam na artha śūnyam avisaṃvādāt
translated: For that knowledge is non-erroneous, not empty of objects, because it is non-deceptive.

original: avisaṃvādaścārthotpateranyarthāmantareṇa bhavato jñānādarthaprāptiravisaṃvādalakṣaṇā mithyā jñānādi na syāt /
analyzed: avisaṃvādaḥ ca artha utpateḥ anyarthām antareṇa bhavataḥ jñānāt artha prāptiḥ avisaṃvāda lakṣaṇā mithyā jñāna ādi na syāt
translated: And non-deceptiveness is the characteristic of non-deception, the attainment of the object from the knowledge that occurs from the object, without another object. If it were not so, knowledge and so on would be false.

analyzed: sā ca artha utpatti tad nvaya vyatirekābhyām
translated: And that is established by the positive and negative concomitance with the arising of the object, of the cognition of the sense faculties such as the learned one.

original: tathā hi timirādidoṣavirahiṇi cakṣuṣi sati jñānaṃ tadabhāve na bhavati /
analyzed: tathā hi timira ādi doṣa virahiṇi cakṣuṣi sati jñānam tad abhāve na bhavati
translated: For thus, when the eye is free from defects such as darkness, there is cognition; when that is absent, it does not occur.

analyzed: nimīlita locanasya satsu api punar unmīlitaḥ bhavati
translated: Even when form, light, and attention are present, it occurs again when the eyes are opened, for one with closed eyes.

original: tathā satyāloke bhavati tadabhāve na bhavati /
analyzed: tathā sati āloke bhavati tad abhāve na bhavati
translated: Similarly, it occurs when there is light; when that is absent, it does not occur.

original: satsvapi anyeṣu cakṣurādiṣu karaṇeṣu punaḥ pradīpādiprakāśe bhavati tathā purovartighaṭādirupasadbhāve bhavati /
analyzed: satsu api anyeṣu cakṣuḥ ādiṣu karaṇeṣu punar pradīpa ādi prakāśe bhavati tathā purovarti ghaṭa ādiḥ upasadbhāve bhavati
translated: Even when the other sense faculties such as the eye are present, it occurs again in the light of a lamp, etc.; similarly, it occurs when the form of a pot in front is present.

analyzed: tad apasāre na bhavati
translated: When that is removed, it does not occur.

original: satsvanyeṣvālokādiṣu punastadbhāve bhavati tathā manaskārābhidhāne vijñāne sati jāyate tadabhāve na bhavati /
analyzed: satsu anyeṣu āloka ādiṣu punar tad bhāve bhavati tathā manaskāra abhidhāne vijñāne sati jāyate tad abhāve na bhavati
translated: Even when other things such as light are present, it occurs again when that is present; similarly, it arises when attention and cognition are present; when that is absent, it does not occur.

analyzed: satsu api ghaṭa ādiṣu ati gāḍha nidrā avasthāyām punar tat prabodhe bhavati
translated: Even when pots, etc. are present, it occurs again when one awakens from very deep sleep.

original: tatraikaikāpāye na tadbhūta jñānasyotpattau sarveṣāṃ sāmarthyamunmīlyate /
analyzed: tatra ekaika apāye na tad bhūta jñānasya utpattau sarveṣām sāmarthyam unmīlyate
translated: There, when one of them is removed, the capacity of all is revealed in the arising of the cognition of that thing.

analyzed: tathā cakṣuṣaḥ tasya rupa pravṛttiḥ na śabda ādau
translated: And thus, the function of the eye is in form, not in sound, etc.

analyzed: na cakṣuṣā śabda ādayaḥ pratīyante
translated: Sounds and so on are not perceived by the eye.

analyzed: śrotra indriya ādīnām parikalpanāyām vaiyartha prasaṅgāt badhira ādīnām abhāva prasaṅgāt ca
translated: Because it would lead to the uselessness of the ear faculty and so on, and because it would lead to the non-existence of the deaf and so on.

analyzed: na ca śabda ādayaḥ tasya janakāḥ
translated: And sounds and so on are not its causes.

analyzed: yena tatra te pratibhāseran
translated: By which they would appear there.

original: ajanakānāmapi pratibhāse sarve'rthāḥ pratyakṣā iti sarvaḥ sarvadarśī syāt /
analyzed: ajanakānām api pratibhāse sarva irthāḥ pratyakṣāḥ iti sarvaḥ sarva darśī syāt
translated: If non-causes also appeared, all objects would be directly perceived, and everyone would see everything.

analyzed: sarvatra indriya jñāna vyavastheyam eva iti cakṣuḥ ādi vijñānam jāyate
translated: This arrangement of sense faculties and cognitions is only in the case of visual consciousness and so on, which arises with the form of the object.

analyzed: na nirākāram anya ākāram vā
translated: Not without form or with another form.

analyzed: tābhyām artha vedanā sambhavāt
translated: Because the experience of the object is not possible with those two.

analyzed: tathā hi yathā sva mukham puruṣasya sarvadā a pratyakṣam
translated: For example, a man's own face is always imperceptible.

analyzed: ālokāt darpaṇe tad pratibimba darśanāt tad anubhavaḥ
translated: By seeing its reflection in a mirror due to light, there is the experience of it.

analyzed: pratibimba anubhavaḥ eva sva mukha rupa anubhavaḥ tasya puruṣasya
translated: The experience of the reflection itself is the experience of the form of one's own face for that man.

analyzed: na pratibimba anubhavāt anyaḥ sākṣāt anuḥ tasya kaścid
translated: There is no direct experience of it other than the experience of the reflection for him.

original: tathā'rthavādināṃ sarveṣāmevārthaḥ kadācidapi na svayaṃ pratyakṣaḥ /
analyzed: tathā artha vādinām sarveṣām eva arthaḥ kadācid api na svayam pratyakṣaḥ
translated: Similarly, for all those who speak of objects, the object is never directly perceived by itself.
The experience of that is the experience of the reflection in the mirror of knowledge.

analyzed: tad darśanam eva artha darśanam
translated: Seeing that is seeing the object.

analyzed: nahi svayam arthaḥ pratyakṣaḥ
translated: The object is not directly perceived by itself.

original: tasya pratyakṣatve pratyakṣātmakatvād vijñānasya vijñānameva vijñānameva syānnārthaḥ /
analyzed: tasya pratyakṣa tve pratyakṣa ātmaka tvāt vijñānasya vijñānam eva vijñānam eva syāt na arthaḥ
translated: If it were directly perceived, then because of the nature of direct perception, consciousness would be only consciousness, not an object.

analyzed: tasya pratyavekṣa tvena jñāna tva āpatteḥ
translated: Because of the attainment of knowledge by the nature of its direct perception.

original: atha artha eva pratyavekṣā na vijñānam /
analyzed: atha artha eva pratyavekṣā na vijñānam
translated: If the object itself is directly perceived, not consciousness,

analyzed: tad apratyakṣa tve sarva apratyakṣa tva prasaṅgaḥ
translated: then if it is not directly perceived, it would follow that everything is not directly perceived.
Because if the reflection is not directly perceived, it cannot be directly perceived like one's own face.

analyzed: tasmāt na arthaḥ pratyakṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, the object is not directly perceived.

original: tatra yadi nīlākārādanyākāraṃ vijñānaṃ syānna nīlākāraṃ tadā sadrūpameva tadvijñānam /
analyzed: tatra yadi nīla ākārāt anya ākāram vijñānam syāt na nīla ākāram tadā sat rūpam eva tat vijñānam
translated: In that case, if consciousness has a form different from the form of blue, then it would not have the form of blue. Then that consciousness would have the form of existence itself.

analyzed: tasya eva tat saṃvedanam na nīlasya nīla ākāra vibhakta tvāt
translated: That is the awareness of that itself, not of the blue, because of the distinction of the form of blue.

original: saṃvedanasya sadasadākāraviviktaṃ na nīlavijñānaṃ pītavijñānaṃ vā /
analyzed: saṃvedanasya sat asat ākāra viviktam na nīla vijñānam pīta vijñānam vā
translated: The awareness is devoid of the form of existence or non-existence. The consciousness of blue is not the consciousness of yellow.

original: yatra yadrūpaṃ na tattasya saṃvedanaṃ yathā pītajñānaṃ kṛṣṇasya /
analyzed: yatra yat rūpam na tat tasya saṃvedanam yathā pīta jñānam kṛṣṇasya
translated: Where there is a form, that is not the awareness of that, like the consciousness of yellow is not of black.

original: yathā darpaṇe svamukhākaraṃ paramukhākāraviviktaṃ svamukhasyaiva saṃvedakam /
analyzed: yathā darpaṇe sva mukha ākaram para mukha ākāra viviktam sva mukhasya eva saṃvedakam
translated: Just as in a mirror, one's own face is separate from the form of another's face, and it is the perceiver of one's own face,

analyzed: na para mukhasya
translated: not of another's face.

analyzed: tad ākāra vivikta tvāt tasya
translated: Because it is separate from that form.

original: tathānyākāraṃ saṃvedanaṃ na nīlākārasya arthasya vedanakātiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: tathā anya ākāram saṃvedanam na nīla ākārasya arthasya vedanaka atiprasaṅgāt
translated: In the same way, a cognition with a different form does not perceive an object with the form of blue, because of the fallacy of over-extension.

analyzed: a saṃvedanāt ca
translated: And because it is not a cognition of that.

analyzed: na api nirākāra vedanam nīla artha vedakam
translated: Nor is a cognition without a form the perceiver of a blue object.

analyzed: tat hi sarva artha ākāra viviktam sarva pratibimba viviktam iva ādarśa maṇḍalam katham arthasya vedakam
translated: For that, being separate from all forms of objects, like a mirror disc devoid of all reflections, how can it be the perceiver of an object?

original: nahi darpaṇatalaṃ nikhilapratibimbarahitaṃ pratibimbavirahiotānāṃ svamukhādīnāṃ vedakam /
analyzed: nahi darpaṇa talam nikhila pratibimba rahitam sva mukha ādīnām vedakam
translated: For a mirror surface devoid of all reflections is not the perceiver of one's own face, etc., which are devoid of reflections.

analyzed: tat vijñānam api rupam ātmani a pratibimbayet
translated: And that cognition also would not reflect the form of some object in itself, by which

analyzed: katham iva artha ābodhakam syāt
translated: how could it be the non-cognizer of an object?

analyzed: na ca arthaḥ sva mukham iva svayam pratyakṣaḥ
translated: And the object is not directly perceived like one's own face,

analyzed: pūrva ukta doṣāt
translated: because of the previously stated fault.

analyzed: tasmāt na anya ākāra nirākārābhyām artha saṃvedana saṃbhavaḥ iti alam atiprasaṅgena
translated: Therefore, the perception of an object by a cognition with a different form or without a form is not possible. Let us stop this digression.

analyzed: diś mātram tu darśitam
translated: Only a direction has been shown.

original: itaḥ paraṃ granthavistarabhayānna likhitam // //🔽svaṃbhavānnādarupād viniṣkrāntāḥ samayācāragocarāḥ /
analyzed: itas param grantha vistara bhayāt na likhitam  svaṃbhavāt nāda rupāt viniṣkrāntāḥ samayācāra gocarāḥ
translated: From here on, it is not written due to fear of the text becoming too extensive.

analyzed: durlabham triṣu lokeṣu ādi madhya anta saṃsthitam
translated: The observances and practices that emerge from the form of the nada are difficult to obtain in the three worlds, existing from beginning to end.

analyzed: kutas evaṃbhūtaḥ saṃbhūtaḥ tvam iti āha saṃbhavāt ityādi
translated: How can one who is such as this be born? It is said from birth and so on.

analyzed: saṃvibhajya devatāḥ bhavanti anena saṃbhavaḥ āli kāli samavāyaḥ
translated: By dividing, one becomes a deity through this birth, the assembly of the moments of the instant.

analyzed: tatra api kutas iti āha na āda rupāt iti
translated: Even there, from where? It is said from the form of the nada.

analyzed: nādaḥ śabda mātram
translated: Nada is mere sound.

analyzed: tasya pratinidhiḥ daṇḍa mātram
translated: Its substitute is merely a stick.

original: tasya rupaṃ svarupaṃ ytahā svāsane svaravyañjanasamūhastadupari hūkāraḥ /
analyzed: tasya rupam svarupam sva āsane svara vyañjana samūhaḥ tad upari hūkāraḥ
translated: Its form is its own form, as in the collection of vowels and consonants in one's own seat, above which is the syllable hūṃ.

analyzed: tat niṣpannam viśva vajram varaṭaka upari
translated: Having placed that accomplished universe-vajra on the tip of the tongue,

analyzed: hūkāram tad upari na antareṇa
translated: the syllable hūṃ is above it, without interruption.

original: kṛṣṇahūkārastadupari rakta āḥkārastadupari śukla omkāro bhāvya iti /
analyzed: kṛṣṇa hūkāraḥ tad upari raktaḥ āḥkāraḥ tad upari śuklaḥ omkāraḥ bhāvyaḥ iti
translated: The black hūṃ is above that, the red āḥ is above that, and the white oṃ should be visualized above that.

analyzed: praṇava ādeḥ niḥsvabhāvīkriyamāṇasya yat nāda mātram
translated: The mere sound of the praṇava and so on being rendered without intrinsic nature,

analyzed: tad nāda mātre tad bindau asau ardhacandraḥ
translated: that mere sound is the drop in that mere sound, and that is the crescent moon.

original: sa omkāre / sa āḥkārasya pārśvabindudvaye tadbahiḥ pārśvadaṇḍe /
analyzed: saḥ omkāre saḥ āḥkārasya pārśva bindu dvaye tad bahis pārśva daṇḍe
translated: It is in the Oṃkāra. It is in the two side dots of the Āḥ syllable, outside of that in the side staff.

analyzed: sa takāra pṛṣṭha lagne pārśva daṇḍe
translated: It is in the side staff attached to the back of the ta syllable.

analyzed: sa takāre
translated: It is in the ta syllable.

analyzed: sa mastake
translated: It is in the head.

analyzed: tat hūkārasya nāda mātram
translated: That is just the sound of the Hūṃ syllable.

original: tannādaṃ sa bindau so'rdhacandre sa mastake /
analyzed: tad nādam sa bindau sa ūrdhacandre sa mastake
translated: That sound is in the bindu, in the half-moon, in the head.

original: tataḥ bindau sa hakāre sa hakārapūrvārdhe sa hakārorā
analyzed: tatas bindau sa hakāre sa hakāra pūrva ardhe sa hakāra ūrā
translated: Then in the bindu, it is in the ha syllable, it is in the first half of the ha syllable, it is in the second half of the ha syllable in the side staffs.

original: 'parārdhe pārśvadaṇḍayostad ukāre sa viśvavajrasthasya hūkārasya nādamātram /🔽tannādaṃ sa bindau sa mastake sa hakārapūrvārdhe sa hakārorā
analyzed: parārdhe pārśva daṇḍayoḥ tat ukāre sa viśva vajra sthasya hūkārasya nāda mātram  tad nādam sa bindau sa mastake sa hakāra pūrva ardhe sa hakāra ūrā
translated: That is in the u syllable, it is just the sound of the Hūṃ syllable in the universal vajra.

analyzed: parārdhe pārśva daṇḍayoḥ
translated: That sound is in the bindu, in the head, it is in the first half of the ha syllable, it is in the second half of the ha syllable in the side staffs.

original: sa ukāre sa viśvavajrasya pūrvapārśvasya madhyaśūke sa vāmaśūke /🔽sa dakṣiṇapārśvasya dakṣiṇaśūke sa madhyaśūke sa vāmaśūke /🔽sa paścimapārśvasya dakṣiṇaśūke sa madhyaśūke sa vāmaśūke /
analyzed: saḥ ukāre sa viśva vajrasya pūrva pārśvasya madhya śūke sa vāma śūke  sa dakṣiṇa pārśvasya dakṣiṇa śūke sa madhya śūke sa vāma śūke  sa paścima pārśvasya dakṣiṇa śūke sa madhya śūke sa vāma śūke
translated: It is in the u syllable, it is in the middle reed of the eastern side of the universal vajra, it is in the left reed.🔽It is in the right reed of the southern side, it is in the middle reed, it is in the left reed.🔽It is in the right reed of the western side, it is in the middle reed, it is in the left reed.

original: sa uttarapārśvasya dakṣiṇaśūke sa madhyasūke sa vāmaśūke /
analyzed: saḥ uttara pārśvasya dakṣiṇa śūke sa madhya sūke sa vāma śūke
translated: It is in the right reed of the northern side, it is in the middle reed, it is in the left reed.

original: sa pūrvapārśvasya dakṣiṇaśūke sa madhyakarṇike sa śūnyatāsvarupe praviṣṭa iti vicintya /
analyzed: sa pūrva pārśvasya dakṣiṇa śūke sa madhya karṇike sa śūnyatā svarupe praviṣṭaḥ iti vicintya
translated: Having contemplated that he has entered into the southern prong of the eastern side, into the central whorl, and into the nature of emptiness,

analyzed: tatas punar pūrva pārśvasya dakṣiṇa śūke
translated: then again into the southern prong of the eastern side,

analyzed: tatas uttara pārśvasya vāmaḥ tatas madhye
translated: then into the left of the northern side, then into the middle,

analyzed: tatas dakṣiṇe
translated: then into the right,

analyzed: tatas paścima pārśvasya vāmaḥ  tatas madhyaḥ tatas dakṣiṇaḥ
translated: then into the left of the western side,🔽then into the middle, then into the right,

analyzed: tatas dakṣiṇa pārśvasya vāma haḥ tatas madhyaḥ tatas dakṣiṇaḥ
translated: then into the left of the southern side, then into the middle, then into the right,

original: tataḥ pūrvapārśvasya vāmastato madhyastato varaṭakasthasya hūkārasyokārastato hakārasyāparārdhapārśvadaṇḍau tābhyāṃ hakārasya pūrvārdham /
analyzed: tatas pūrva pārśvasya vāmaḥ tatas madhyaḥ tatas varaṭaka sthasya hūkārasya ukāraḥ tatas hakārasya apara ardha pārśva daṇḍau tābhyām hakārasya pūrva ardham
translated: then into the left of the eastern side, then into the middle, then into the ū syllable of the huṃ syllable located in the thunderbolt, then into the lower half of the ha syllable, then into the side stick of the ha syllable, from those two into the upper half of the ha syllable,

analyzed: tatas mastake tatas binduḥ
translated: then into the head, then into the half-moon, then into the dot,

analyzed: tatas nādaḥ  tatas nāda mātram
translated: then into the sound,🔽then into the mere sound,

analyzed: tatas ukāraḥ tatas hakāraḥ rā

analyzed: vāma aṅguṣṭhena bhūmim vilikhate yā tu guru janaḥ me rakṣitavyam iti uktam bhavati

analyzed: akṣiṇī unmīlayet yā tu evam kuruṣva iti vaktavyam bhavati

analyzed: parvaṇī lehayet yā tu sukha śayanam iti uktam bhavati

original: yāni kānicid dūtīnāṃ tān sarvān pradarśayet // //
analyzed: yāni kānicid dūtīnām tān sarvān pradarśayet
translated: Whatever signs the messengers have, she should display them all.

original: iti śrīherukābhidhāne sarvayoginya hasta mudrāsaṃketavidhipaṭalo viṃśatimaḥ // //
analyzed: iti śrī heruka abhidhāne sarvayoginya hasta mudrāsaṃketavidhi paṭalaḥ viṃśatimaḥ  /

analyzed: dakṣiṇa hasta chommakam āha dakṣiṇa ityādi su bodham

analyzed: sarvāsām yoginīnām hasta mudrāḥ saṅketāḥ ca ete vidhīyante yena sa ca asau paṭalaḥ ca iti sarva yoginī hasta mudrā saṅketa vidhi paṭalaḥ viṃśatimaḥ viṃśatitamaḥ

translated: The mantra practitioner should show the index finger slightly bent.

analyzed: mudrā potaṅgī nāma aṅgamudrāḥ prakīrtitāḥ iti pāṭha antare potaṅginī iti nāmnyaḥ mudrāḥ tāḥ ca āha netramudrām vijānīyāt kiñcid
